I car share very often so I needed a quick and accurate way to bill my friends and vice-versa. This web/mobile app allows you to input the details of the journey including distance travelled, average MPG and number of passengers and automatically bill accounts using Paypal.

Built With

  • ios
  • node.js
  • paypal

Originally we wanted to build an Android application but abandoned the idea after spending 5odd hours of trying to set up Eclipse and the Android Developer tools on everyone's laptop.

Soo we eventually settled on building a web app in Node (Much Javascript and HTML), which we have both never done before. In the end we managed to get a web app that uses Google Maps and Braintree running, which we are both incredibly happy with.

The thing we are most proud of is getting something with a bunch of moving parts running despite having never used any of the languages and frameworks before.

Built With

  • braintree
  • google-maps
  • html
  • javascript
  • node.js
  • policeapi
  • web

  • github.com

Make people look like Cristiano Betta; What more would want?

The initial idea came from a mixture of wanting to use the Microsoft Kinect sdk and the mention of a prize for the best use of Cristiano Betta's face.

This meant that we started out with the idea of using the Kinect's camera to track a person and replace their head/face with Cristiano's. We got this working and then thought to expand this to an android app.

The android app opens a view of the camera and whenever it detects a face in its viewfinder it will replace the persons face with one of Cristiano's. We also implemented the braintree api to allow payments for more of Cristiano's faces to be used.

Built With

  • braintree-api
  • java
  • kinect
  • android
  • windows

First of all, we were amused by all the thing that we were offered to use in our hack, especially hardware such as Oculus Rift, that we had always wished to try. The opportunity arose, and we would not let it pass by untouched. At this point we decided that we would use Oculus Rift and one of the alternate forms of Human-Computer Interraction that were offered. Among the possibilities, after a quick amount of research, we chose Myo for the easyness of use. Since we were going to use Oculus Rift and alternative input, we decided that the best way of doing this would be through a game. The concept we tried to implement was the idea of a runner in which you dont controll the trajectory of the player, but the enviornment. For example, instead of moving around an obstacle you move the obstacle out of the way. We thought that we would be able to implement the general concept by 22h, and would work on our other ideas after the first working version. We were terribly wrong. After nearly double the time we had expected and more caffeine than we would like to admit, we finnally had a working version, but with a couple of issues. The most saddening being the fact that Oculus Rift and Myo did not interact well together in the project, so Myo would sometimes not properly work with oculus in the project :`( . The issue seems to be relatively easily solvable, but we did not have the time to solve it, since we preferred to implement the mechanics using myo. Also we could not implement other ideas such as enemies being generated ad hoc based on stocks values got from bloomberg, and some simple in-game purchases using Braintree. We could not do that because actually learning how to use both hardwares and integrating them with the enviornment was really time-consuming, so we had few time to actually have the game working and do some tuning.

Built With

  • c#
  • javascript
  • unity
  • hardware
  • windows

We started off with the intention of making an arcade game. We then experimented with procedural generation for the environment which resulted in an "endless/infinite runner" style game. After this, we implemented a highscore table API to add a competitive element to the game.

Some key features we are proud of the the highscore API integration using GameJolt, and the procedurally generated terrain that allows for infinite gameplay.

  • gamemaker
  • gamejolt
  • windows

After hearing both the talks from Braintree and Bloomberg, it just felt natural to combine the two technologies into an app that allows anyone to buy very reliable stocks with the touch of a button. It takes all the charts and statistics that go along with financial maths, and simplifies them down into a single characteristic, risk, using the Bloomberg API as a backend. Then, it gives you the most reliable stocks to choose from and allows you to buy them via Braintrees API.

Built With

  • bloomberg
  • braintree-api
  • android
